JCUA POTW 2C RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN



1.  The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies.



The Jackson County Utility Authority's Emergency Response Plan is used to provide clear, concise directions during an emergency.  Its function is to prevent physical harm to the staff, the public, or the plant facilities.



This plan is a key to preparedness and was developed using EPA guidelines.  The Emergency Response Plan includes a series of action plans for specific situations and lists emergency supplies, emergency organizations, and emergency telephone numbers.



The Emergency Response Plan is comprised of the following action plans for emergency situations:



*  Emergency Telephone Numbers

*  First Aid Procedures

*  Chemical Emergencies

*  Electrical Emergencies

*  Weather Emergencies

*  Material Safety Data Sheets



Insofar as possible, every contingency has been covered under the Authority's Emergency Response Plan. Specific details of the Emergency Response Plan are included in a separate binder maintained at the facility.  



The Authority's wastewater treatment facilities have safety systems for the prevention of an accidental release.  These systems include the following:



*  Leak Detector System

*  Automatic Emergency Shut Off System 

*  Manual Shut Off System 

*  Call-Out System

*  Safety Inspections



The leak detector system monitors the chlorine/sulfur dioxide storage area ans the feed control station for chemical leaks. The Automatic Emergency Shut Off System operates an automatic valve shutoff actuator that will shut down the gas system upon leak detection. The leak detector system is connected to an audible alarm horn and warning light located on the chlorine/sulfur dioxide storage building.  In the event of a leak, the alarm system will activate and alert plant personnel or the call-out man via the plant's automatic dialing alarm system(ADAS). Responding personnel then implem

ent the Emergency Response Plan and follow the pertinent procedure.



The call-out system provides the Authority with a dedicated employee available 24 hours a day to respond to emergency situations at the wastewater facilities.



The safety inspections are conducted by the Safety Committee by use of an inspection check list.  These inspections are conducted on a semi-annual basis.  The inspections are reviewed by each department head and any safety infraction is corrected.  The safety inspection ensures that a safe working environment is maintained at all times.



With the use of these safety systems, the Authority provides safety of not only plant personnel, but the community around the facilities.



2.  The stationary source and regulated substance handled.



The JCUA POTW2C (Gautier) Wastewater Treatment plant treats domestic wastewater from the city of Gautier.



Chlorine is applied to the treatment plant effluent for the purpose of disinfection and sulfur dioxide is used for chlorine removal prior to discharge to the West Pascagoula River.



The facility stores two one-ton containers of chlorine and two one-ton containers of sulfur dioxide.  This  equates to a four month supply on hand.  The facility operates with one container on line and one container on stand-by.



3.  The worst-case release scenario:



The worst-case release scenario was based on the failure of a pipe line connected to a storage container containing 2,000 pounds of chlorine, with a 10 minute release time.



Utilizing urban conditions with a wind speed of 1.5 meters per second, class F stability, the toxic end point would be 0.0087 at a distance of 1.3 miles.



The residential population within this distance is 3,000.  Public and environmental receptors within the distance that would be affected include schools, recreational areas, industrial areas, state parks, monuments, and a wildlife refuge.



Alternate-case release scenario:



The alternate-case release scenario was based

on the failure of a 1/4 inch puncture of a pipe line connected to a container containing 2,000 pounds of chlorine, with a 10 minute release time.



Utilizing urban conditions with a wind speed of 3.0 meters per second, class D stability, the toxic end point would be 0.0087 at a distance of 0.3 miles.



The residential population within this distance is 153.  Public and environmental receptors within the distance that would be affected include recreational areas, and a wildlife refuge.



The chlorine/sulfur dioxide building is covered and partially enclosed.  This minimizes the potential for overheating of the ton container.



The gas feeder on the container is designed to shut off the supply of gas in case of a line breakage.



The chlorine/sulfur dioxide building is also equipped with a leak detector system and automatic shut off system.  In the event of a leak, the system will trigger an actuator that closes the valve.  In addition, an alarm will activate, alerting the plant personnel.  Plant personnel then respond in accordance with the Emergency Plan procedures.  



4.  The accidental release prevention program.



There are several key steps to the Gautier Regional Wastewater Treatment plant's prevention plan.



*  Maintenance Service Agreement (changes out valves and regulators)

*  Call-Out System

*  Leak Detector System

*  Safety Inspections

*  Safety Training



5.  Five-year accident history.



The Gautier Regional Wastewater Treatment plant has not had an accidental release of chlorine or sulfur dioxide over the past five years.



6.  Emergency Response Program.



The Authority participates in the Community Right to Know, SARA Title III, Tier 2 program.  The JCUA participates in the EPlan Hazmat Emergency Response system online reporting notified by Tier II  Reporting system that is required by the EPA. E-Plan is a proven system that provides First Responders and others with on-site hazardous chemical information for facilities around the Uni

ted States.  It utilized emergency contact and hazardous material information submitted under the US Environmental Protection Agency regulations and sends it via the internet to First Responders just when they need it the most. This facility ifnormation is also provided to the the Jackson County Office of Emergency Services and the Gautier Fire Department.



7.  Safety Improvements.



In 2017 the Authority added the automatic shut off system.  Prior to that, in April, 1999, the Authority installed a new chlorine and sulfur dioxide leak detector to monitor the ton cylinder storage area for any chlorine or sulfur dioxide leaks.  Also, an existing chlorine leak detector inside the feed control station was replaced with an upgraded leak detector.  With the addition of the new leak detectors at the ton cylinder storage area, this provides a complete chlorine and sulfur dioxide leak detector monitoring system.  In August 2006, upgraded chlorine and sulfur dioxide regulators and vacuum sensors were installed.
